title: Physics
description: Motion, forces, energy, and basic physical laws.

questions.prompt: Newton’s First Law is often explained using the concept of…
questions.explanation: Newton’s First Law says an object stays at rest or in uniform straight-line motion unless acted on by a net external force—this resistance to change is inertia.

questions.prompt: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: A newton (N) is the SI unit of force.

questions.prompt: Near Earth’s surface, the acceleration due to gravity is approximately…
questions.explanation: On Earth, g is about 9.81 m/s² (it varies slightly by location).

questions.prompt: The conservation of energy means that energy…
choices: Cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed
questions.explanation: Within a closed system, total energy remains constant, though it can change forms (kinetic, potential, thermal, etc.).

questions.prompt: What is the SI unit of energy?
questions.explanation: A joule (J) is the SI unit of energy and work.

questions.prompt: Which formula gives kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy of an object moving at speed v is KE = ½mv².

questions.prompt: For small swings, the period of a simple pendulum depends mostly on…
questions.explanation: For small angles, T ≈ 2π√(L/g). Mass does not appear in the ideal formula.

questions.prompt: What is the main difference between speed and velocity?
questions.explanation: Speed is a scalar (how fast), while velocity is a vector (how fast and in what direction).

questions.prompt: Why doesn’t the Moon fall straight down to Earth?
choices: It is moving sideways fast enough to keep orbiting
There is no gravity in space
The Moon is held up by air
questions.explanation: The Moon is constantly falling toward Earth, but its sideways velocity makes it keep missing—this is orbit.

questions.prompt: A Möbius strip is special because it has…
questions.explanation: A Möbius strip is a non‑orientable surface: it has only one side and one boundary curve.

questions.prompt: The speed of light in vacuum is exactly…
questions.explanation: By definition, the speed of light in vacuum c is exactly 299,792,458 m/s (≈ 300,000 km/s).

questions.prompt: Ohm’s law relates voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) as…
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law for many conductors: V = I × R.

questions.prompt: Newton’s Second Law is commonly written as…
questions.explanation: Net force equals mass times acceleration.

questions.prompt: Newton’s Third Law says that…
choices: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction
Objects keep moving unless a force acts on them
questions.explanation: Forces come in pairs between interacting objects.

questions.prompt: What is the SI unit of power?
questions.explanation: Power is energy per unit time; 1 watt = 1 joule/second.

questions.prompt: Momentum is defined as…
questions.explanation: Linear momentum p = mv.

questions.prompt: The SI unit of frequency is…
questions.explanation: 1 hertz means one cycle per second.

questions.prompt: What is the SI unit of electric charge?
questions.explanation: Charge is measured in coulombs.

questions.prompt: Wave speed is given by…
questions.explanation: Speed equals frequency times wavelength.

questions.prompt: In a simple series circuit, the current is…
questions.explanation: Series components share the same current; voltage divides across them.
